entities: Group of Experts on the Democratic Republic of the Congo
International Conference on the Great Lakes Region
reporting_cycle: Secretary-General reports every 90 days, through the Committee, by 18 May 2012 and again before 19 October 2012
summary:
9. States are recommended to publish import and export statistics for natural resources and enhance information sharing to combat regional criminal networks.

10. MONUSCO's mandate to support Congolese authorities in preventing support to armed groups from illicit activities is recalled.

11. The Government of the Democratic Republic of the Congo is encouraged to enhance stockpile security, accountability, and management of arms and ammunition.

12. The Government of the Democratic Republic of the Congo is encouraged to address the underlying issue of national Army cohesion.

13. All armed groups are demanded to lay down their arms and cease violence, human rights abuses, and international humanitarian law violations.

14. The Congolese authorities' efforts to fight against impunity are welcomed, and their continuation is encouraged.

15. The Congolese Government is stressed to actively seek to hold accountable those responsible for war crimes and crimes against humanity.

16. Enhanced cooperation between States, MONUSCO, and the Group of Experts is encouraged.

17. The Group of Experts is called upon to cooperate with other relevant panels of experts.

18. MONUSCO is encouraged to take into account the Group of Experts' findings.

19. States are called upon to report to the Committee on actions taken to implement measures imposed by paragraphs 1, 2, and 3.
The Security Council:

20. Encourages all States to submit to the Committee individuals or entities meeting the criteria set out in paragraph 4 of resolution 1857 (2008), including entities owned or controlled by them, for inclusion on its list of designees;

21. Decides to review the measures set forth in this resolution by 30 November 2012, with a view to adjusting them as appropriate, in light of the security situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, including progress in security sector reform and disarming, demobilizing, repatriating, resettling and reintegrating armed groups;

22. Decides to remain actively seized of the matter.
